Pick a well-defined task (high priority, clear spec, no blockers)\n3. Work on it until completion or stuck\n4. Commit and complete the task\n5. Exit cleanly (the outer loop restarts with fresh context)\n\nKey features from research:\n- Simple core: while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude ; done\n- Context persists via filesystem/git, not session memory\n- Dual-condition exit: require both completion indicator AND explicit exit signal\n- Circuit breaker: stop after N loops with no progress or repeated errors\n- Rate limiting for API calls\n\nKspec-specific additions:\n- Task selection heuristics (prioritize: clear AC, no blockers, isolated scope)\n- Progress tracking via task notes before each exit\n- Session checkpoint before exit to ensure clean state\n- Maybe: task budget (only attempt tasks under estimated N turns)\n\nThe beauty is each iteration starts fresh but inherits cumulative work. ## Working Procedure

1. **Pick a task**: Review ready_tasks above. Pick the highest priority task (lowest number = higher priority). If there's an active (in_progress) task, continue that instead.

2. **Start the task** (if not already in_progress):
   ```bash
   kspec task start @task-ref
   ```

3. **Do the work**:
   - Read relevant files to understand the task
   - Make changes as needed
   - Run tests if applicable
   - Document as you go with task notes

4. **Document progress**:
   ```bash
   kspec task note @task-ref "What you did, decisions made, etc."
   ```

5. **Submit or checkpoint**:
   - If code is DONE (ready for PR):
     ```bash
     kspec task submit @task-ref
     ```
   - If task is NOT done (WIP):
     ```bash
     kspec task note @task-ref "WIP: What's done, what remains..."
     ```

6. **Commit your work**:
   ```bash
   git add -A && git commit -m "feat/fix/chore: description

   Task: @task-ref"
   ```

7. **Reflect on this iteration**:
   Think about what you learned, any friction points, or patterns worth remembering.

   For **systemic patterns** (friction or success worth documenting):
   ```bash
   kspec meta observe friction "Description of systemic issue..."
   kspec meta observe success "Pattern worth replicating..."
   ```

   For **actionable improvements** (specific ideas that could become tasks):
   ```bash
   kspec inbox add "Improvement idea..." --tag reflection
   ```

## Important Notes
- Stay focused on ONE task per iteration
- The loop continues automatically - don't worry about picking the next task
- kspec tracks state across iterations via task status and notes
- Always commit before the iteration ends
- Always reflect and capture at least one observation

availableCommands.name: audit
availableCommands.description: Comprehensive codebase audit for release readiness. Parallel exploration of docs, code, config, tests, and specs to identify cruft, then interactive triage with clear action options. (project)

availableCommands.name: kspec
availableCommands.description: Use kspec CLI for task and spec management. Invoke when working with tasks, tracking work, capturing ideas, checking session status, or managing specs in this project. (project)

availableCommands.name: meta
availableCommands.description: Manage session context - focus, threads, questions, and observations. Use when tracking what you're working on, managing parallel work streams, or capturing friction points. (project)

availableCommands.name: pr
availableCommands.description: Create a pull request from current work. Handles branch creation, commits, push, and PR creation. Detects branch protection and guides through the PR workflow. (project)

availableCommands.name: reflect
availableCommands.description: Reflect on a session to identify learnings, friction points, and improvements. Captures valuable insights for future sessions and system evolution. (project)

availableCommands.name: spec-plan
availableCommands.description: Translate an approved plan into specs with acceptance criteria and derived tasks. Use after plan mode when transitioning to implementation. (project)

availableCommands.name: triage
availableCommands.description: Triage inbox items systematically. Analyzes items against spec/tasks, categorizes them, and processes using spec-first approach with plan mode for larger features. (project)

availableCommands.name: compact
availableCommands.description: Clear conversation history but keep a summary in context. Optional: /compact [instructions for summarization]

availableCommands.name: init
availableCommands.description: Initialize a new CLAUDE.md file with codebase documentation

availableCommands.name: pr-comments
availableCommands.description: Get comments from a GitHub pull request

availableCommands.name: review
availableCommands.description: Review a pull request

availableCommands.name: security-review
availableCommands.description: Complete a security review of the pending changes on the current branch

Pick a well-defined task (high priority, clear spec, no blockers)\n3. Work on it until completion or stuck\n4. Commit and complete the task\n5. Exit cleanly (the outer loop restarts with fresh context)\n\nKey features from research:\n- Simple core: while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude ; done\n- Context persists via filesystem/git, not session memory\n- Dual-condition exit: require both completion indicator AND explicit exit signal\n- Circuit breaker: stop after N loops with no progress or repeated errors\n- Rate limiting for API calls\n\nKspec-specific additions:\n- Task selection heuristics (prioritize: clear AC, no blockers, isolated scope)\n- Progress tracking via task notes before each exit\n- Session checkpoint before exit to ensure clean state\n- Maybe: task budget (only attempt tasks under estimated N turns)\n\nThe beauty is each iteration starts fresh but inherits cumulative work. ## Working Procedure

1. **Pick a task**: Review ready_tasks above. Pick the highest priority task (lowest number = higher priority). If there's an active (in_progress) task, continue that instead.

2. **Start the task** (if not already in_progress):
   ```bash
   kspec task start @task-ref
   ```

3. **Do the work**:
   - Read relevant files to understand the task
   - Make changes as needed
   - Run tests if applicable
   - Document as you go with task notes

4. **Document progress**:
   ```bash
   kspec task note @task-ref "What you did, decisions made, etc."
   ```

5. **Submit or checkpoint**:
   - If code is DONE (ready for PR):
     ```bash
     kspec task submit @task-ref
     ```
   - If task is NOT done (WIP):
     ```bash
     kspec task note @task-ref "WIP: What's done, what remains..."
     ```

6. **Commit your work**:
   ```bash
   git add -A && git commit -m "feat/fix/chore: description

   Task: @task-ref"
   ```

7. **Reflect on this iteration**:
   Think about what you learned, any friction points, or patterns worth remembering.

   For **systemic patterns** (friction or success worth documenting):
   ```bash
   kspec meta observe friction "Description of systemic issue..."
   kspec meta observe success "Pattern worth replicating..."
   ```

   For **actionable improvements** (specific ideas that could become tasks):
   ```bash
   kspec inbox add "Improvement idea..." --tag reflection
   ```

## Important Notes
- Stay focused on ONE task per iteration
- The loop continues automatically - don't worry about picking the next task
- kspec tracks state across iterations via task status and notes
- Always commit before the iteration ends
- Always reflect and capture at least one observation

    36→  path: z.string(),
    37→  function: z.string().optional(),
    38→  lines: z.string().optional(),
    39→});
    40→
    41→/**
    42→ * Traceability block
    43→ */
    44→export const TraceabilitySchema = z.object({
    45→  implementation: z.array(ImplementationRefSchema).optional(),
    46→  tests: z.array(z.object({ path: z.string() })).optional(),
    47→  commits: z.array(z.string()).optional(),
    48→  issues: z.array(z.string()).optional(),
    49→});
    50→
    51→/**
    52→ * Full spec item schema
    53→ */
    54→export const SpecItemSchema = z.object({
    55→  // Identity
    56→  _ulid: UlidSchema,
    57→  slugs: z.array(SlugSchema).default([]),
    58→  title: z.string().min(1, 'Title is required'),
    59→  type: ItemTypeSchema.optional(),
    60→
    61→  // Status
    62→  status: StatusSchema.optional(),
    63→
    64→  // Classification
    65→  priority: PrioritySchema.optional(),
    66→  tags: z.array(z.string()).default([]),
    67→
    68→  // Content
    69→  description: z.string().optional(),
    70→  acceptance_criteria: z.array(AcceptanceCriterionSchema).optional(),
    71→
    72→  // Relationships (references start with @)
    73→  depends_on: z.array(RefSchema).default([]),
    74→  implements: z.array(RefSchema).default([]),
    75→  relates_to: z.array(RefSchema).default([]),
    76→  tests: z.array(RefSchema).default([]),
    77→  traits: z.array(RefSchema).default([]),
    78→  supersedes: RefSchema.nullable().optional(),
    79→
    80→  // Traceability
    81→  traceability: TraceabilitySchema.optional(),
    82→
    83→  // Lifecycle
    84→  created: DateTimeSchema.optional(),
    85→  created_by: z.string().optional(),
    86→  deprecated_in: z.string().nullable().optional(),
    87→  superseded_by: RefSchema.nullable().optional(),
    88→
    89→  // Notes (work log / implementation context)
    90→  notes: z.array(NoteSchema).default([]),
    91→});
    92→
    93→/**
    94→ * Spec item input schema (for creating new items, ULID auto-generated)
    95→ */
    96→export const SpecItemInputSchema = SpecItemSchema.omit({ _ulid: true }).extend({
    97→  _ulid: UlidSchema.optional(),
    98→});
    99→
   100→/**

Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

_ulid: 01JHNKA1W2SCHM000000000000
slugs:
  - schema
  - schema-module
title: Schema and Structure
type: module
status:
  maturity: draft
  implementation: implemented
description: |
  Defines the schema layer: what item types exist, how validation
  works, the file structure options, and the status lifecycle
  for both specs and individual items.
features:
  - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W3TYPE000000000000
    slugs:
      - item-types
      - type-system
    title: Item Type System
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      The type field classifies items. Core types are defined,
      but the system is extensible for project-specific types.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W4TYPE100000000000
        slugs:
          - type-module
        title: Module Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: module

          High-level organizational unit. Groups related features.
          Examples: "Authentication", "API", "Data Export"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W5TYPE200000000000
        slugs:
          - type-feature
        title: Feature Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: feature

          User-facing capability. Something the system does.
          Examples: "User Login", "Data Export", "Search"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W6TYPE300000000000
        slugs:
          - type-requirement
        title: Requirement Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: requirement

          Specific, testable requirement. Details how a feature works.
          Examples: "Passwords must be hashed with bcrypt"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W7TYPE400000000000
        slugs:
          - type-constraint
        title: Constraint Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: constraint

          Limitation or boundary the system must operate within.
          Examples: "Must support 10k concurrent users", "Must use PostgreSQL"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W8TYPE500000000000
        slugs:
          - type-decision
        title: Decision Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: decision

          Architectural decision record (ADR-style).
          Captures why a choice was made, alternatives considered.
          Examples: "Use PostgreSQL for persistence", "Choose YAML over JSON"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W9TYPE600000000000
        slugs:
          - type-task
        title: Task Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: task (and subtypes: epic, bug, spike, infra)

          Actionable work item. May be derived from spec items
          or created standalone. See @tasks module for details.
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
        relates_to:
          - "@tasks"
  - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W0STAT000000000000
    slugs:
      - status-lifecycle
      - item-status
    title: Status Lifecycle
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      Items track two dimensions of status:
      - maturity: How stable/reviewed is the spec content?
      - implementation: Is it built? Tested?
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W1STAT100000000000
        slugs:
          - maturity-states
        title: Maturity States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |-
          status.maturity tracks spec content stability:

          - draft: Initial capture, may change significantly
          - proposed: Ready for review, seeking approval
          - stable: Approved, changes require process
          - deferred: Intentionally postponed, not abandoned
          - deprecated: Superseded or no longer relevant

          Lifecycle: draft -> proposed -> stable -> deprecated
                      draft -> deferred (for stub specs)
                      deferred -> draft (when resuming work)
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: "a spec item with maturity: deferred"
            when: viewing or filtering items
            then: the deferred status is recognized and displayed correctly
          - id: ac-2
            given: creating or updating a spec item
            when: setting maturity to deferred
            then: the value is accepted and persisted
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W2STAT200000000000
        slugs:
          - implementation-states
        title: Implementation States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          status.implementation tracks build progress:

          - not_started: No work begun
          - in_progress: Currently being implemented
          - implemented: Code complete
          - verified: Tests pass, reviewed

          This is informational; tasks track actual work.
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
      - _ulid: 01KF3H95B873EP62X4A2GBD5FC
        slugs:
          - status-cascade
        title: Cascade Status Updates
        type: requirement
        tags:
          - dx
          - cli
        description: When updating a parent item's implementation status, CLI offers to cascade the update
          to nested children. Prevents status drift between parent features and child requirements.
        depends_on: []
        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:52:53.609Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The command completes
            then: "CLI prompts: 'Update N child items to implemented? [y/n]'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'y' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is accepted
            then: All child items are updated to 'implemented' and each child update is logged
          - id: ac-3
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'n' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is rejected
            then: Child items are NOT updated and retain their original status
          - id: ac-4
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented
              --json'
            when: JSON mode is active
            then: No cascade prompt is shown and children are NOT automatically updated
          - id: ac-5
            given: A parent item has NO children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The update completes
            then: No cascade prompt is shown (since there are no children to cascade to)
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: in_progress
  - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3R05F1FTXTS8WS035
    slugs:

        description: |
          For larger projects, split into directories:

          project/
            spec/

              modules/

                api.yaml
              decisions/

        type: requirement
        status:

        description: |
          The CLI can suggest splitting when specs grow:
          - Threshold: ~500 lines or 20+ items
          - `kspec split --suggest` shows recommendations
          - `kspec split --apply` restructures (with git-friendly renames)

          Not MVP - this is a convenience feature.
        implements:
          - "@file-structure"
  - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3K12YTFTPFB1EHC63
    slugs:
      - yaml-conventions
      - yaml-safety
    title: YAML Conventions
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: not_started
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      YAML has pitfalls (Norway problem, type coercion).
      These conventions ensure safe, predictable parsing.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3Z9T0AWQGEJ3GW2WZ
        slugs:
          - yaml-version
        title: YAML 1.2 Required
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Parsers MUST use YAML 1.2 (not 1.1).
          YAML 1.1 has dangerous implicit typing:
          - "NO" -> false
          - "on" -> true
          - "3.14" might become float

          YAML 1.2 is stricter and safer.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3MFX4H51TN64GEB6T
        slugs:
          - yaml-quoting
        title: Quote Ambiguous Strings
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Strings that might be misinterpreted MUST be quoted:
          - "NO", "YES", "true", "false", "on", "off"
          - Numbers that should be strings: "3.14", "1.0"
          - Special values: "null", "~"

          The linter should catch unquoted ambiguous values.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3M7T6ZNEMTVYBWP96
        slugs:
          - yaml-multiline
        title: Multiline with Literal Blocks
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Multiline strings SHOULD use literal block style (|):

          description: |
            This is a multiline description.
            It preserves newlines.

          This is cleaner than quoted strings with \n.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"

    slugs:

    title: Schema Validation
    type: feature
    status:

      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:

    description: |
      Validation ensures specs conform to schema and conventions.
      Schema is defined in Zod (source of truth), exported to JSON Schema.
    acceptance_criteria:
      - id: ac-valid-1
        given: a spec with all required fields
        when: kspec validate runs
        then: validation passes with exit code 0
      - id: ac-valid-2
        given: a spec with a broken @reference
        when: kspec validate --refs runs
        then: validation fails with error listing broken ref
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3MRSVNT5E9ETQD72W
        slugs:
          - zod-schema
        title: Zod Schema Definition
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Schema is defined using Zod (TypeScript validation library):
          - Source of truth for item structure
          - z.infer<> generates TypeScript types
          - z.toJSONSchema() exports JSON Schema for docs/external tools

          Zod chosen for ecosystem size, type inference, JSON Schema export.
        implements:
          - "@validation"
        depends_on:
          - "@spec-item"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ373KGN2PK8P3XQ929
        slugs:
          - validation-modes
        title: Validation Modes
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          `kspec validate` supports multiple modes:
          - --schema: Check schema conformance only
          - --refs: Check all @references resolve
          - --orphans: Find items not referenced by anything
          - (default): All checks

          CI should run `kspec validate` or `kspec lint --strict`.
        implements:
          - "@validation"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ42RZQPFC962QV2TP3
        slugs:

        title: Validation Output
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Validation output includes:
          - List of errors (must fix)
          - List of warnings (should fix)
          - Summary counts

          JSON output (--json) for programmatic consumption:
          { "valid": false, "errors": [...], "warnings": [...] }
        implements:
          - "@validation"

        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:44:30.558Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A spec item exists without acceptance_criteria
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: "A warning is shown: 'Item @slug has no acceptance criteria'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A spec item exists without a description

          - id: ac-3

          - id: ac-2

slugs:

title: Schema and Structure
type: module
status:
  maturity: draft
  implementation: implemented
description: |
  Defines the schema layer: what item types exist, how validation
  works, the file structure options, and the status lifecycle
  for both specs and individual items.
features:
  - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W3TYPE000000000000
    slugs:
      - item-types
      - type-system
    title: Item Type System
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      The type field classifies items. Core types are defined,
      but the system is extensible for project-specific types.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W4TYPE100000000000
        slugs:
          - type-module
        title: Module Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: module

          High-level organizational unit. Groups related features.
          Examples: "Authentication", "API", "Data Export"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W5TYPE200000000000
        slugs:
          - type-feature
        title: Feature Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: feature

          User-facing capability. Something the system does.
          Examples: "User Login", "Data Export", "Search"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W6TYPE300000000000
        slugs:
          - type-requirement
        title: Requirement Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: requirement

          Specific, testable requirement. Details how a feature works.
          Examples: "Passwords must be hashed with bcrypt"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W7TYPE400000000000
        slugs:
          - type-constraint
        title: Constraint Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: constraint

          Limitation or boundary the system must operate within.
          Examples: "Must support 10k concurrent users", "Must use PostgreSQL"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W8TYPE500000000000
        slugs:
          - type-decision
        title: Decision Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: decision

          Architectural decision record (ADR-style).
          Captures why a choice was made, alternatives considered.
          Examples: "Use PostgreSQL for persistence", "Choose YAML over JSON"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W9TYPE600000000000
        slugs:
          - type-task
        title: Task Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: task (and subtypes: epic, bug, spike, infra)

          Actionable work item. May be derived from spec items
          or created standalone. See @tasks module for details.
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
        relates_to:
          - "@tasks"
  - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W0STAT000000000000
    slugs:
      - status-lifecycle
      - item-status
    title: Status Lifecycle
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      Items track two dimensions of status:
      - maturity: How stable/reviewed is the spec content?
      - implementation: Is it built? Tested?
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W1STAT100000000000
        slugs:
          - maturity-states
        title: Maturity States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |-
          status.maturity tracks spec content stability:

          - draft: Initial capture, may change significantly
          - proposed: Ready for review, seeking approval
          - stable: Approved, changes require process
          - deferred: Intentionally postponed, not abandoned
          - deprecated: Superseded or no longer relevant

          Lifecycle: draft -> proposed -> stable -> deprecated
                      draft -> deferred (for stub specs)
                      deferred -> draft (when resuming work)
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: "a spec item with maturity: deferred"
            when: viewing or filtering items
            then: the deferred status is recognized and displayed correctly
          - id: ac-2
            given: creating or updating a spec item
            when: setting maturity to deferred
            then: the value is accepted and persisted
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W2STAT200000000000
        slugs:
          - implementation-states
        title: Implementation States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          status.implementation tracks build progress:

          - not_started: No work begun
          - in_progress: Currently being implemented
          - implemented: Code complete
          - verified: Tests pass, reviewed

          This is informational; tasks track actual work.
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
      - _ulid: 01KF3H95B873EP62X4A2GBD5FC
        slugs:
          - status-cascade
        title: Cascade Status Updates
        type: requirement
        tags:
          - dx
          - cli
        description: When updating a parent item's implementation status, CLI offers to cascade the update
          to nested children. Prevents status drift between parent features and child requirements.
        depends_on: []
        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:52:53.609Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The command completes
            then: "CLI prompts: 'Update N child items to implemented? [y/n]'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'y' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is accepted
            then: All child items are updated to 'implemented' and each child update is logged
          - id: ac-3
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'n' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is rejected
            then: Child items are NOT updated and retain their original status
          - id: ac-4
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented
              --json'
            when: JSON mode is active
            then: No cascade prompt is shown and children are NOT automatically updated
          - id: ac-5
            given: A parent item has NO children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The update completes
            then: No cascade prompt is shown (since there are no children to cascade to)
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: in_progress

  - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3K12YTFTPFB1EHC63
    slugs:
      - yaml-conventions
      - yaml-safety
    title: YAML Conventions
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: not_started
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    traits:
      - "@01KFDZD3"
    description: |
      YAML has pitfalls (Norway problem, type coercion).
      These conventions ensure safe, predictable parsing.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3Z9T0AWQGEJ3GW2WZ
        slugs:
          - yaml-version
        title: YAML 1.2 Required
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Parsers MUST use YAML 1.2 (not 1.1).
          YAML 1.1 has dangerous implicit typing:
          - "NO" -> false
          - "on" -> true
          - "3.14" might become float

          YAML 1.2 is stricter and safer.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3MFX4H51TN64GEB6T
        slugs:
          - yaml-quoting
        title: Quote Ambiguous Strings
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Strings that might be misinterpreted MUST be quoted:
          - "NO", "YES", "true", "false", "on", "off"
          - Numbers that should be strings: "3.14", "1.0"
          - Special values: "null", "~"

          The linter should catch unquoted ambiguous values.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3M7T6ZNEMTVYBWP96
        slugs:
          - yaml-multiline
        title: Multiline with Literal Blocks
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Multiline strings SHOULD use literal block style (|):

          description: |
            This is a multiline description.
            It preserves newlines.

          This is cleaner than quoted strings with \n.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"

          - --refs: Check all @references resolve

          CI should run `kspec validate` or `kspec lint --strict`.

    slugs:

      - spec-versions
    title: Versioning
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: medium
    tags:
      - schema
    description: |
      Two version numbers: format version and spec version.
      Git provides history; tags provide baselines.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA3W6VERS100000000000
        slugs:
          - format-version
        title: Format Version
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          The `kynetic` field in manifest declares format version:

          kynetic: "1.0"

          Tools use this to know which schema to apply.
          Breaking format changes bump major version.
        implements:
          - "@versioning"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA3W7VERS200000000000
        slugs:
          - spec-version
        title: Spec Version
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          The `project.version` field tracks the spec's own version:

          project:
            version: "1.2.3"

          Follows semver:
          - MAJOR: Breaking requirement changes
          - MINOR: New requirements, non-breaking clarifications
          - PATCH: Typos, editorial
        implements:
          - "@versioning"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA3W8VERS300000000000
        slugs:
          - git-baselines
        title: Git Tag Baselines
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Use annotated git tags for spec baselines:

          git tag -a spec-v1.0.0 -m "Initial stable release"

          Enables: kspec diff --since spec-v1.0.0
        implements:
          - "@versioning"

            given: user runs 'kspec trait add <title>'

          - id: ac-6

          - id: ac-2

features:
  - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W3TYPE000000000000

        status:

  - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W0STAT000000000000
    slugs:
      - status-lifecycle
      - item-status
    title: Status Lifecycle
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      Items track two dimensions of status:
      - maturity: How stable/reviewed is the spec content?
      - implementation: Is it built? Tested?
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W1STAT100000000000
        slugs:
          - maturity-states
        title: Maturity States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |-
          status.maturity tracks spec content stability:

          - draft: Initial capture, may change significantly
          - proposed: Ready for review, seeking approval
          - stable: Approved, changes require process
          - deferred: Intentionally postponed, not abandoned
          - deprecated: Superseded or no longer relevant

          Lifecycle: draft -> proposed -> stable -> deprecated
                      draft -> deferred (for stub specs)
                      deferred -> draft (when resuming work)
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: "a spec item with maturity: deferred"
            when: viewing or filtering items
            then: the deferred status is recognized and displayed correctly
          - id: ac-2
            given: creating or updating a spec item
            when: setting maturity to deferred
            then: the value is accepted and persisted
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W2STAT200000000000
        slugs:
          - implementation-states
        title: Implementation States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          status.implementation tracks build progress:

          - not_started: No work begun
          - in_progress: Currently being implemented
          - implemented: Code complete
          - verified: Tests pass, reviewed

          This is informational; tasks track actual work.
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
      - _ulid: 01KF3H95B873EP62X4A2GBD5FC
        slugs:
          - status-cascade
        title: Cascade Status Updates
        type: requirement
        tags:
          - dx
          - cli
        description: When updating a parent item's implementation status, CLI offers to cascade the update
          to nested children. Prevents status drift between parent features and child requirements.
        depends_on: []
        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:52:53.609Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The command completes
            then: "CLI prompts: 'Update N child items to implemented? [y/n]'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'y' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is accepted
            then: All child items are updated to 'implemented' and each child update is logged
          - id: ac-3
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'n' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is rejected
            then: Child items are NOT updated and retain their original status
          - id: ac-4
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented
              --json'
            when: JSON mode is active
            then: No cascade prompt is shown and children are NOT automatically updated
          - id: ac-5
            given: A parent item has NO children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The update completes
            then: No cascade prompt is shown (since there are no children to cascade to)
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: in_progress

          The CLI can suggest splitting when specs grow:
          - Threshold: ~500 lines or 20+ items
          - `kspec split --suggest` shows recommendations

        implements:

  - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3K12YTFTPFB1EHC63
    slugs:
      - yaml-conventions
      - yaml-safety
    title: YAML Conventions
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: not_started
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      YAML has pitfalls (Norway problem, type coercion).
      These conventions ensure safe, predictable parsing.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3Z9T0AWQGEJ3GW2WZ
        slugs:
          - yaml-version
        title: YAML 1.2 Required
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Parsers MUST use YAML 1.2 (not 1.1).
          YAML 1.1 has dangerous implicit typing:
          - "NO" -> false
          - "on" -> true
          - "3.14" might become float

          YAML 1.2 is stricter and safer.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3MFX4H51TN64GEB6T
        slugs:
          - yaml-quoting
        title: Quote Ambiguous Strings
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Strings that might be misinterpreted MUST be quoted:
          - "NO", "YES", "true", "false", "on", "off"
          - Numbers that should be strings: "3.14", "1.0"
          - Special values: "null", "~"

          The linter should catch unquoted ambiguous values.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3M7T6ZNEMTVYBWP96
        slugs:
          - yaml-multiline
        title: Multiline with Literal Blocks
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Multiline strings SHOULD use literal block style (|):

          description: |
            This is a multiline description.
            It preserves newlines.

          This is cleaner than quoted strings with \n.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
  - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ36HXNV019K1S25BNM
    slugs:
      - validation

    title: Schema Validation
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      Validation ensures specs conform to schema and conventions.
      Schema is defined in Zod (source of truth), exported to JSON Schema.
    acceptance_criteria:
      - id: ac-valid-1
        given: a spec with all required fields
        when: kspec validate runs
        then: validation passes with exit code 0
      - id: ac-valid-2
        given: a spec with a broken @reference
        when: kspec validate --refs runs
        then: validation fails with error listing broken ref
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3MRSVNT5E9ETQD72W
        slugs:
          - zod-schema
        title: Zod Schema Definition
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Schema is defined using Zod (TypeScript validation library):
          - Source of truth for item structure
          - z.infer<> generates TypeScript types
          - z.toJSONSchema() exports JSON Schema for docs/external tools

          Zod chosen for ecosystem size, type inference, JSON Schema export.
        implements:
          - "@validation"
        depends_on:
          - "@spec-item"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ373KGN2PK8P3XQ929
        slugs:
          - validation-modes
        title: Validation Modes
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          `kspec validate` supports multiple modes:
          - --schema: Check schema conformance only
          - --refs: Check all @references resolve
          - --orphans: Find items not referenced by anything
          - (default): All checks

          CI should run `kspec validate` or `kspec lint --strict`.
        implements:
          - "@validation"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ42RZQPFC962QV2TP3
        slugs:
          - validation-output
        title: Validation Output
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Validation output includes:
          - List of errors (must fix)
          - List of warnings (should fix)
          - Summary counts

          JSON output (--json) for programmatic consumption:
          { "valid": false, "errors": [...], "warnings": [...] }
        implements:
          - "@validation"
      - _ulid: 01KF3GST2YDS6MA1A04WK7A9FJ
        slugs:

        tags: []

          specs to help maintain spec-as-source-of-truth principle.
        depends_on: []
        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:44:30.558Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A spec item exists without acceptance_criteria
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: "A warning is shown: 'Item @slug has no acceptance criteria'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A spec item exists without a description
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs

          - id: ac-3

          - id: ac-4

            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: A summary is shown with counts by issue type (e.g., '3 items missing AC, 2 status mismatches')

          implementation: implemented

      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W4TYPE100000000000

          - type-module

        status:

        slugs:
          - type-feature
        title: Feature Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |

          Examples: "User Login", "Data Export", "Search"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W6TYPE300000000000
        slugs:
          - type-requirement
        title: Requirement Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: requirement

          Specific, testable requirement. Details how a feature works.
          Examples: "Passwords must be hashed with bcrypt"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W7TYPE400000000000
        slugs:
          - type-constraint
        title: Constraint Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: constraint

          Limitation or boundary the system must operate within.
          Examples: "Must support 10k concurrent users", "Must use PostgreSQL"
        implements:
          - "@item-types"
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W8TYPE500000000000
        slugs:
          - type-decision
        title: Decision Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |

        implements:

      - _ulid: 01JHNKA1W9TYPE600000000000
        slugs:
          - type-task
        title: Task Type
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |
          type: task (and subtypes: epic, bug, spike, infra)

          Actionable work item. May be derived from spec items
          or created standalone. See @tasks module for details.
        implements:

        relates_to:
          - "@tasks"
  - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W0STAT000000000000
    slugs:
      - status-lifecycle
      - item-status
    title: Status Lifecycle
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: implemented
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    description: |
      Items track two dimensions of status:
      - maturity: How stable/reviewed is the spec content?
      - implementation: Is it built? Tested?
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W1STAT100000000000
        slugs:
          - maturity-states
        title: Maturity States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: verified
        description: |-
          status.maturity tracks spec content stability:

          - draft: Initial capture, may change significantly
          - proposed: Ready for review, seeking approval
          - stable: Approved, changes require process
          - deferred: Intentionally postponed, not abandoned
          - deprecated: Superseded or no longer relevant

          Lifecycle: draft -> proposed -> stable -> deprecated
                      draft -> deferred (for stub specs)
                      deferred -> draft (when resuming work)
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: "a spec item with maturity: deferred"
            when: viewing or filtering items
            then: the deferred status is recognized and displayed correctly
          - id: ac-2
            given: creating or updating a spec item
            when: setting maturity to deferred
            then: the value is accepted and persisted
      - _ulid: 01JHNKA2W2STAT200000000000
        slugs:
          - implementation-states
        title: Implementation States
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          status.implementation tracks build progress:

          - not_started: No work begun
          - in_progress: Currently being implemented
          - implemented: Code complete
          - verified: Tests pass, reviewed

          This is informational; tasks track actual work.
        implements:
          - "@status-lifecycle"
      - _ulid: 01KF3H95B873EP62X4A2GBD5FC
        slugs:
          - status-cascade
        title: Cascade Status Updates
        type: requirement
        tags:
          - dx
          - cli
        description: When updating a parent item's implementation status, CLI offers to cascade the update
          to nested children. Prevents status drift between parent features and child requirements.
        depends_on: []
        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:52:53.609Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The command completes
            then: "CLI prompts: 'Update N child items to implemented? [y/n]'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'y' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is accepted
            then: All child items are updated to 'implemented' and each child update is logged
          - id: ac-3
            given: A parent item has children, user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented',
              and user responds 'n' to the cascade prompt
            when: The cascade is rejected
            then: Child items are NOT updated and retain their original status
          - id: ac-4
            given: A parent item has children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation implemented
              --json'
            when: JSON mode is active
            then: No cascade prompt is shown and children are NOT automatically updated
          - id: ac-5
            given: A parent item has NO children and user runs 'kspec item set @parent --implementation
              implemented'
            when: The update completes
            then: No cascade prompt is shown (since there are no children to cascade to)
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: in_progress

        description: |

            spec/

              modules/

                api.yaml
              decisions/

          Uses `includes` field in manifest to reference files.
        implements:

        implements:

    slugs:

    title: YAML Conventions
    type: feature
    status:
      maturity: draft
      implementation: not_started
    priority: high
    tags:
      - mvp
      - schema
    traits:
      - "@01KFDZD3"
    description: |
      YAML has pitfalls (Norway problem, type coercion).
      These conventions ensure safe, predictable parsing.
    requirements:
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3Z9T0AWQGEJ3GW2WZ
        slugs:
          - yaml-version
        title: YAML 1.2 Required
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Parsers MUST use YAML 1.2 (not 1.1).
          YAML 1.1 has dangerous implicit typing:
          - "NO" -> false
          - "on" -> true
          - "3.14" might become float

          YAML 1.2 is stricter and safer.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3MFX4H51TN64GEB6T
        slugs:
          - yaml-quoting
        title: Quote Ambiguous Strings
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Strings that might be misinterpreted MUST be quoted:
          - "NO", "YES", "true", "false", "on", "off"
          - Numbers that should be strings: "3.14", "1.0"
          - Special values: "null", "~"

          The linter should catch unquoted ambiguous values.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ3M7T6ZNEMTVYBWP96
        slugs:
          - yaml-multiline
        title: Multiline with Literal Blocks
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: not_started
        description: |
          Multiline strings SHOULD use literal block style (|):

          description: |
            This is a multiline description.
            It preserves newlines.

          This is cleaner than quoted strings with \n.
        implements:
          - "@yaml-conventions"
  - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ36HXNV019K1S25BNM
    slugs:

    title: Schema Validation

      - schema
    description: |
      Validation ensures specs conform to schema and conventions.
      Schema is defined in Zod (source of truth), exported to JSON Schema.
    acceptance_criteria:
      - id: ac-valid-1
        given: a spec with all required fields
        when: kspec validate runs
        then: validation passes with exit code 0
      - id: ac-valid-2
        given: a spec with a broken @reference
        when: kspec validate --refs runs
        then: validation fails with error listing broken ref

        slugs:

        title: Zod Schema Definition
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Schema is defined using Zod (TypeScript validation library):
          - Source of truth for item structure
          - z.infer<> generates TypeScript types
          - z.toJSONSchema() exports JSON Schema for docs/external tools

          Zod chosen for ecosystem size, type inference, JSON Schema export.
        implements:
          - "@validation"
        depends_on:
          - "@spec-item"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ373KGN2PK8P3XQ929
        slugs:
          - validation-modes
        title: Validation Modes
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          `kspec validate` supports multiple modes:
          - --schema: Check schema conformance only
          - --refs: Check all @references resolve
          - --orphans: Find items not referenced by anything
          - (default): All checks

          CI should run `kspec validate` or `kspec lint --strict`.
        implements:
          - "@validation"
      - _ulid: 01KEZCJPJ42RZQPFC962QV2TP3
        slugs:
          - validation-output
        title: Validation Output
        type: requirement
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented
        description: |
          Validation output includes:
          - List of errors (must fix)
          - List of warnings (should fix)
          - Summary counts

          JSON output (--json) for programmatic consumption:
          { "valid": false, "errors": [...], "warnings": [...] }
        implements:
          - "@validation"

          specs to help maintain spec-as-source-of-truth principle.
        depends_on: []
        implements: []
        relates_to: []
        tests: []
        created: 2026-01-16T13:44:30.558Z
        acceptance_criteria:
          - id: ac-1
            given: A spec item exists without acceptance_criteria
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: "A warning is shown: 'Item @slug has no acceptance criteria'"
          - id: ac-2
            given: A spec item exists without a description
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: "A warning is shown: 'Item @slug has no description'"
          - id: ac-3
            given: A parent item has implementation:implemented but children have not_started
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: A warning is shown about status inconsistency between parent and children
          - id: ac-4
            given: Multiple completeness issues exist
            when: kspec validate --completeness runs
            then: A summary is shown with counts by issue type (e.g., '3 items missing AC, 2 status mismatches')
        status:
          maturity: draft
          implementation: implemented

          - MAJOR: Breaking requirement changes

Core idea: a script that runs Claude Code repeatedly with fresh context, using a templated prompt that instructs it to:\n\n1. Run 'kspec session start' to see ready tasks\n2. Pick a well-defined task (high priority, clear spec, no blockers)\n3. Work on it until completion or stuck\n4. Commit and complete the task\n5. Exit cleanly (the outer loop restarts with fresh context)\n\nKey features from research:\n- Simple core: while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude ; done\n- Context persists via filesystem/git, not session memory\n- Dual-condition exit: require both completion indicator AND explicit exit signal\n- Circuit breaker: stop after N loops with no progress or repeated errors\n- Rate limiting for API calls\n\nKspec-specific additions:\n- Task selection heuristics (prioritize: clear AC, no blockers, isolated scope)\n- Progress tracking via task notes before each exit\n- Session checkpoint before exit to ensure clean state\n- Maybe: task budget (only attempt tasks under estimated N turns)\n\nThe beauty is each iteration starts fresh but inherits cumulative work.     "total_tasks": 236,

    "pending_review": 1,

    "inbox_items": 22
  }

```

## Working Procedure

1. **Pick a task**: Review ready_tasks above. Pick the highest priority task (lowest number = higher priority). If there's an active (in_progress) task, continue that instead.

2. **Start the task** (if not already in_progress):
   ```bash
   kspec task start @task-ref
   ```

3. **Do the work**:
   - Read relevant files to understand the task
   - Make changes as needed
   - Run tests if applicable
   - Document as you go with task notes

4. **Document progress**:
   ```bash
   kspec task note @task-ref "What you did, decisions made, etc."
   ```

5. **Submit or checkpoint**:
   - If code is DONE (ready for PR):
     ```bash
     kspec task submit @task-ref
     ```
   - If task is NOT done (WIP):
     ```bash
     kspec task note @task-ref "WIP: What's done, what remains..."
     ```

6. **Commit your work**:
   ```bash
   git add -A && git commit -m "feat/fix/chore: description

   Task: @task-ref"
   ```

7. **Reflect on this iteration**:
   Think about what you learned, any friction points, or patterns worth remembering.

   For **systemic patterns** (friction or success worth documenting):
   ```bash
   kspec meta observe friction "Description of systemic issue..."
   kspec meta observe success "Pattern worth replicating..."
   ```

   For **actionable improvements** (specific ideas that could become tasks):
   ```bash
   kspec inbox add "Improvement idea..." --tag reflection
   ```

## Important Notes
- Stay focused on ONE task per iteration
- The loop continues automatically - don't worry about picking the next task
- kspec tracks state across iterations via task status and notes
- Always commit before the iteration ends
- Always reflect and capture at least one observation

file.content:
# Spec Trait Adoption & AC Gap Analysis Plan

## Overview

Comprehensive spec refactoring to:
1. Create reusable traits for cross-cutting CLI patterns
2. Fill acceptance criteria gaps across all modules
3. Apply traits to existing specs to reduce duplication and ensure consistency

**Note**: This plan produces **tasks** to do the work, not direct spec modifications.

## Analysis Summary

### Traits to Create (8 Core Traits)

Based on analysis of 50+ CLI commands, these 8 patterns repeat across 4+ commands each:

| Trait | Description | Commands Using |
|-------|-------------|----------------|
| `@trait-json-output` | `--json` flag, consistent JSON structure | 12+ commands |
| `@trait-multi-ref-batch` | `--refs @a @b` batch operations | 5+ commands |
| `@trait-confirmation-prompt` | `--force` to skip confirmation | 4+ commands |
| `@trait-filterable-list` | `--status`, `--tag`, `--limit` filters | 7+ commands |
| `@trait-priority-parameter` | `--priority 1-5` scale | 7+ commands |
| `@trait-dry-run` | `--dry-run` preview mode | 6+ commands |
| `@trait-semantic-exit-codes` | 0/1/2/3/4/5 exit code meanings | All commands |
| `@trait-error-guidance` | Error messages with recovery suggestions | All commands |

**Note on multi-ref**: The existing `@multi-ref-batch` feature has good AC but should also exist as a trait. As a trait, adding multi-ref support to a new command means adding `traits: [@trait-multi-ref-batch]` rather than updating the feature spec (proper direction of change).

**Deferred patterns** (lower priority, may become traits later):
- Task state machine (domain-specific to tasks)
- Reference resolution (infrastructure, not command pattern)
- Append-only notes (domain-specific)
- Nested hierarchy (structural, not behavioral)
- Slug uniqueness (validation concern)
- Implementation status tracking (domain-specific)
- Meta associations (domain-specific)
- Verbosity levels (--verbose/--full)
- Tree vs flat display modes
- Spec-task alignment (domain-specific)
- Slug generation (infrastructure)
- Preview with limits (subset of dry-run)

### AC Coverage Gaps

**Methodology**: Counting only items with `type: requirement` or `type: feature` that describe testable behavior but have zero AC. Modules, decisions, and purely definitional items are excluded.

**Items requiring AC: ~70 critical items** (subset of ~177 total items without AC)

Critical gaps (must fix - these describe behavior):
- `@type-module`, `@type-feature`, `@type-requirement`, `@type-constraint`, `@type-decision`, `@type-task` (schema.yaml) - 6 items
- `@task-type-task`, `@task-type-epic`, `@task-type-bug`, `@task-type-spike`, `@task-type-infra` (tasks.yaml) - 5 items
- `@yaml-version`, `@yaml-quoting`, `@yaml-multiline` (schema.yaml) - 3 items
- `@rel-blocks`, `@rel-implements`, `@rel-relates-to` (core.yaml) - 3 items

High priority gaps:
- Various CLI command specs missing error case AC
- Task schema fields missing validation AC
- Meta CLI commands missing edge case AC

**Note**: Many items without AC are definitional (modules, design principles) and don't require AC.

### Code/Spec Misalignment

| Issue | Severity | Status |
|-------|----------|--------|
| Task `automation` field missing from schema | HIGH | Spec exists, no code |
| YAML convention validation | MEDIUM | Spec exists, no code |
| Auto-adaptive file splitting | MEDIUM | Spec exists, no code |
| Validation completeness (parent-child status) | LOW | Partially implemented |

### Structural Issues

- **auth.yaml**: Referenced in manifest but doesn't exist - **DECISION: Remove from manifest** (no auth-related specs exist in the project)
- CLI module is 2684 lines (oversized vs ~500 for others) - **Deferred**: Document recommendation but don't split in this work

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 0: Validate Trait System (Pre-flight)

Before creating traits, verify the trait system works end-to-end:

1. Create a single test trait via `kspec trait add "Test Trait" --description "Validation test"`
2. Add one AC to it
3. Verify `kspec trait list` shows the trait
4. Apply it to a spec item and verify `kspec item get @spec` shows inherited AC
5. Delete the test trait if successful, or investigate if issues

**Why**: No traits exist currently. The system is implemented but untested in production.

### Phase 1: Create Core Traits (8 traits)

Create trait definitions in `kynetic.yaml` root-level `traits` array:

```yaml
# kynetic.yaml
traits:
  - _ulid: <generated>
    slugs: [trait-json-output]
    title: JSON Output Mode
    type: trait
    description: Commands support --json flag for structured JSON output
    acceptance_criteria:
      - id: ac-1
        given: command supports JSON mode
        when: --json flag provided
        then: output is valid JSON with no ANSI color codes
      - id: ac-2
        given: JSON mode active
        when: command completes
        then: output includes all data available in human mode
      # ... more AC per trait
```

**Traits to create (8 total):**
1. `@trait-json-output` (6 AC) - JSON output mode support
2. `@trait-multi-ref-batch` (8 AC) - Batch operations via --refs flag
3. `@trait-confirmation-prompt` (6 AC) - Destructive operation confirmation
4. `@trait-filterable-list` (7 AC) - List filtering and pagination
5. `@trait-priority-parameter` (6 AC) - Priority 1-5 scale
6. `@trait-dry-run` (6 AC) - Preview mode
7. `@trait-semantic-exit-codes` (8 AC) - Consistent exit code meanings
8. `@trait-error-guidance` (6 AC) - Error messages with suggestions

**Location decision**: Traits go in `kynetic.yaml` (not a separate module) because:
- Traits are cross-cutting, not domain-specific
- The trait CLI already reads/writes to manifest
- Keeps traits visible at project root level

### Phase 2: Fill Critical AC Gaps (17 items)

Add acceptance criteria to items that describe testable behavior but have zero AC:

**schema.yaml type requirements (6 items)**:
- `@type-module`: AC for module validation, nesting rules
- `@type-feature`: AC for feature structure
- `@type-requirement`: AC for requirement structure
- `@type-constraint`: AC for constraint validation
- `@type-decision`: AC for decision records
- `@type-task`: AC for task-type items in specs

**tasks.yaml type requirements (5 items)**:
- `@task-type-task`: AC for default task behavior
- `@task-type-epic`: AC for epic-child relationships
- `@task-type-bug`: AC for bug-specific behavior
- `@task-type-spike`: AC for spike outcomes
- `@task-type-infra`: AC for infrastructure tasks

**core.yaml relationship requirements (3 items)**:
- `@rel-blocks`: AC for blocking relationship behavior
- `@rel-implements`: AC for implementation tracking
- `@rel-relates-to`: AC for informational links

**schema.yaml YAML requirements (3 items)**:
- `@yaml-version`: AC for YAML 1.2 enforcement
- `@yaml-quoting`: AC for quote validation rules
- `@yaml-multiline`: AC for multiline format rules

### Phase 3: Apply Traits to Existing Specs

Update CLI command specs to declare traits they implement:

```yaml
# Example: @cmd-task-complete
- _ulid: ...
  slugs: [cmd-task-complete]
  title: kspec task complete
  type: requirement
  traits:
    - "@trait-json-output"
    - "@trait-multi-ref-batch"
    - "@trait-semantic-exit-codes"
    - "@trait-error-guidance"
  # Spec's own AC now only cover command-specific behavior
  acceptance_criteria:
    - id: ac-specific-1
      given: task in in_progress state
      when: kspec task complete @ref
      then: status changes to completed
```

**Commands to update (highest value first)**:
1. Task lifecycle commands (start, complete, cancel, block, unblock, submit, delete) - 7 commands
2. Item CRUD commands (add, get, list, set, delete) - 5 commands
3. Query commands (tasks list, tasks ready, tasks blocked, search) - 4 commands
4. Inbox commands (add, list, promote, delete) - 4 commands

### Phase 4: Fix Structural Issues

1. **Remove auth.yaml from manifest** (or create stub if needed)
2. **Consider CLI split** (lower priority - document recommendation only)

## Deliverables

This plan produces **standalone tasks** - each can be worked independently:

| Task | Description | Priority |
|------|-------------|----------|
| Validate trait system E2E | Create test trait, verify inheritance works, clean up. Confirms system is production-ready. | P1 |
| Create 8 core traits | Create trait-json-output, trait-multi-ref-batch, trait-confirmation-prompt, trait-filterable-list, trait-priority-parameter, trait-dry-run, trait-semantic-exit-codes, trait-error-guidance in kynetic.yaml with full AC. | P1 |
| Add AC to 17 critical spec items | Add acceptance criteria to type requirements (6), task type requirements (5), relationship requirements (3), YAML requirements (3) in schema.yaml, tasks.yaml, core.yaml. | P1 |
| Remove auth.yaml from manifest | Edit kynetic.yaml to remove the modules/auth.yaml include (file doesn't exist). | P1 |
| Apply traits to task lifecycle commands | Add traits field to @cmd-task-start, @cmd-task-complete, @cmd-task-cancel, @cmd-task-block, @cmd-task-unblock, @cmd-task-submit, @cmd-task-delete specs in cli.yaml. | P2 |
| Apply traits to item CRUD commands | Add traits field to @cmd-item-add, @cmd-item-get, @cmd-item-list, @cmd-item-set, @cmd-item-delete specs in cli.yaml. | P2 |
| Apply traits to query and inbox commands | Add traits field to @cmd-tasks-list, @cmd-tasks-ready, @cmd-tasks-blocked, @cmd-search, @cmd-inbox-add, @cmd-inbox-list, @cmd-inbox-promote, @cmd-inbox-delete specs in cli.yaml. | P3 |

**Priority mapping**: P1 = priority 1, P2 = priority 2, P3 = priority 3 (in kspec task system)

## Verification

After implementation:
1. `kspec validate` passes with no errors
2. `kspec trait list` shows 8 traits with AC counts
3. `kspec validate --completeness` shows reduced warnings
4. Commands with traits show inherited AC in `kspec item get @cmd-*`
5. Test trait inheritance: verify a spec with `traits: [@trait-json-output]` shows inherited AC

## Files to Modify

- `.kspec/kynetic.yaml` - Add traits array, remove auth.yaml reference
- `.kspec/modules/schema.yaml` - Add AC to type requirements
- `.kspec/modules/tasks.yaml` - Add AC to task type requirements
- `.kspec/modules/core.yaml` - Add AC to relationship requirements
- `.kspec/modules/cli.yaml` - Add traits field to CLI command specs

## Risks & Mitigations

| Risk | Mitigation |
|------|------------|
| Trait AC may conflict with spec-specific AC | Review each spec's existing AC before applying trait |
| Large number of spec updates may introduce errors | Run `kspec validate` after each batch of changes |
| Trait system has bugs (never used in production) | Phase 0 validates system before committing to 8 traits |

## Resolved Questions

1. ~~Should `@multi-ref-batch` be a trait?~~ **Yes** - traits define cross-cutting patterns; adding multi-ref to a new command should mean adding the trait, not updating a feature spec
2. ~~Where do traits live?~~ **kynetic.yaml** - cross-cutting, already supported by CLI
3. ~~Priority for applying traits?~~ **Incrementally** - task commands first (P2), then item commands (P2), then queries (P3)

## Out of Scope

- CLI module splitting (recommended for future work, not this effort)
- Deferred trait patterns (12 lower-priority patterns documented above)

     0→import { z } from 'zod';
     1→
     2→// Common types used across spec and task schemas
     3→
     4→/**
     5→ * ULID pattern - 26 character Crockford base32
     6→ * Excludes I, L, O, U to avoid confusion with 1, 1, 0, V
     7→ */
     8→export const ulidPattern = /^[0-9A-HJKMNP-TV-Z]{26}$/i;
     9→
    10→/**
    11→ * Slug pattern - lowercase alphanumeric with hyphens
    12→ */
    13→export const slugPattern = /^[a-z][a-z0-9-]*$/;
    14→
    15→/**
    16→ * Reference pattern - @ prefix followed by slug or ULID (or short ULID)
    17→ */
    18→export const refPattern = /^@[a-zA-Z0-9-]+$/;
    19→
    20→// Base schemas
    21→export const UlidSchema = z.string().regex(ulidPattern, 'Invalid ULID format');
    22→export const SlugSchema = z.string().regex(slugPattern, 'Invalid slug format');
    23→export const RefSchema = z.string().regex(refPattern, 'Invalid reference format');
    24→
    25→// Priority can be string or number
    26→export const PrioritySchema = z.union([
    27→  z.enum(['high', 'medium', 'low']),
    28→  z.number().int().min(1).max(5),
    29→]);
    30→
    31→// ISO 8601 date or datetime
    32→export const DateTimeSchema = z.union([
    33→  z.string().datetime(),
    34→  z.string().date(),
    35→]);
    36→
    37→// Maturity status
    38→export const MaturitySchema = z.enum(['draft', 'proposed', 'stable', 'deferred', 'deprecated']);
    39→
    40→// Implementation status
    41→export const ImplementationStatusSchema = z.enum([
    42→  'not_started',
    43→  'in_progress',
    44→  'implemented',
    45→  'verified',
    46→]);
    47→
    48→// Task status
    49→export const TaskStatusSchema = z.enum([
    50→  'pending',
    51→  'in_progress',
    52→  'pending_review',
    53→  'blocked',
    54→  'completed',
    55→  'cancelled',
    56→]);
    57→
    58→// Task type
    59→export const TaskTypeSchema = z.enum([
    60→  'epic',
    61→  'task',
    62→  'bug',
    63→  'spike',
    64→  'infra',
    65→]);
    66→
    67→// Item type
    68→export const ItemTypeSchema = z.enum([
    69→  'module',
    70→  'feature',
    71→  'requirement',
    72→  'constraint',
    73→  'decision',
    74→  'task',
    75→  'trait',
    76→]);
    77→
    78→// VCS reference
    79→export const VcsRefSchema = z.object({
    80→  ref: z.string(),
    81→  type: z.enum(['branch', 'tag', 'commit']).optional(),
    82→});
    83→
    84→export type Ulid = z.infer<typeof UlidSchema>;
    85→export type Slug = z.infer<typeof SlugSchema>;
    86→export type Ref = z.infer<typeof RefSchema>;
    87→export type Priority = z.infer<typeof PrioritySchema>;
    88→export type DateTime = z.infer<typeof DateTimeSchema>;
    89→export type Maturity = z.infer<typeof MaturitySchema>;
    90→export type ImplementationStatus = z.infer<typeof ImplementationStatusSchema>;
    91→export type TaskStatus = z.infer<typeof TaskStatusSchema>;
    92→export type TaskType = z.infer<typeof TaskTypeSchema>;
    93→export type ItemType = z.infer<typeof ItemTypeSchema>;
    94→export type VcsRef = z.infer<typeof VcsRefSchema>;
    95→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>
```
